misconceptions.name: Implemented a different problem instead of the specified number guessing game
misconceptions.description: The student wrote a road trip cost calculator instead of a number guessing game, so none of the required behaviors (random number generation, guessing loop, high/low hints, correct-guess termination) are present.
misconceptions.student_belief: I can solve this question by writing a program that calculates the cost of a road trip using distance, miles per gallon, and fuel price.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: The program should implement a number guessing game where the computer picks a random number between 1 and 100, repeatedly prompts the user to guess, and after each incorrect guess prints whether the guess was too high or too low until the correct guess is made.
symptoms: Class and program focus on road trip cost instead of a guessing game
No use of Random or generation of a secret number between 1 and 100
No loop for repeated guessing
No 'Too high' or 'Too low' feedback messages
No termination condition based on a correct guess
misconceptions.root_cause: Likely confusion between assignment questions or reuse of code from a different exercise without adapting it to the current specification.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Re-read the problem statement carefully and start from scratch: first generate a random number 1–100, then use a loop to read guesses and compare them to the secret number, printing 'Too high', 'Too low', or a success message as appropriate.
related_concepts: Loops and conditionals for interactive programs
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: Every part of the program is about trip cost calculation and there is no trace of any number guessing game logic.

evidence.note: Class name and variables show the program is about a road trip cost calculator, not a number guessing game.
All input/output relates to trip cost calculation; there is no guessing prompt, random number, or high/low feedback.

misconceptions.correct_understanding: The submitted code must implement a loop-based guessing game that uses random number generation and provides 'Too high'/'Too low' feedback.

Variables relate to distance and fuel costs, not game numbers or guesses

misconceptions.root_cause: The student submitted the solution for a different, unrelated assignment or question.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Please review the assignment prompt carefully and ensure you upload the correct file containing the Number Guessing Game implementation.
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: The code explicitly performs cost calculation using distance, MPG, and price, proving it is not the required guessing game.

Variables are defined for cost calculation, not for a guessing game.

misconceptions.name: Wrong problem solved
misconceptions.description: Student submitted code for a completely different problem (Road Trip Cost Calculator) instead of the Number Guessing Game assignment.
misconceptions.student_belief: The student appears to have submitted code from a different assignment or misunderstood which problem to solve.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: The assignment requires implementing a Number Guessing Game where the computer picks a random number 1-100 and the user guesses until correct, with 'Too high' and 'Too low' hints.
symptoms: Code reads distance, mpg, and fuel price instead of implementing a guessing game
No Random number generation for a secret number
No loop for multiple guesses
No conditional logic for high/low feedback
Program calculates trip cost instead of playing a game
misconceptions.root_cause: Student submitted code for an entirely different problem (likely a previous or concurrent assignment about calculating road trip costs).
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Re-read the Q2 problem statement carefully. You need to create a guessing game using Random.nextInt(100)+1, a while loop for guesses, and if-else logic to provide feedback.
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: Absolute certainty - the submitted code solves an entirely different problem (road trip cost calculation) with no connection to the number guessing game requirements.

evidence.note: Class name and variable declarations are for road trip cost calculation, not a number guessing game
All prompts and calculations are for road trip cost, not a guessing game

misconceptions.name: Implemented wrong problem (no number guessing game)
misconceptions.description: The student implemented a road trip cost calculator instead of the requested number guessing game. The program has no random number generation, guessing loop, or high/low feedback logic, so it does not address any of the required game behavior.
misconceptions.student_belief: I should write a program that calculates the cost of a road trip based on distance, miles per gallon, and fuel price.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: The task is to write an interactive number guessing game where the computer chooses a random number between 1 and 100, and the user repeatedly guesses until correct, receiving 'Too high' or 'Too low' feedback after each incorrect guess.
symptoms: Program prompts for driving distance, miles per gallon, and fuel price instead of guesses.
No use of Random or any random number generation.
No loop to allow multiple guesses.
No conditional logic for 'Too high' or 'Too low' messages.
Program performs a single arithmetic calculation and exits.
misconceptions.root_cause: The student appears to have confused this question with a different assignment (road trip cost calculator) and did not implement the specified number guessing game at all.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Re-read the problem statement carefully and design the program around the required behavior: generate a random answer, then use a loop and conditionals to process repeated user guesses with appropriate feedback.
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: Every part of the code is focused on a road trip cost calculation and there is no trace of any number guessing game elements.

evidence.note: Entire program is a road trip cost calculator with no random number, no guessing loop, and no high/low feedback, showing the problem specification was not followed.
